stem: A 16-year-old client with anorexia nervosa is being monitored for cardiovascular stability. Based on the documentation in the Serial Orthostatic & Cardiac Surveillance Log, what is the most urgent action the nurse should take?

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: 1215: Client reports significant 'lightheadedness' and 'shaking' when attempting to walk to the bathroom. Skin is cool and mottled in lower extremities. CRT 4 seconds.

tabs.title: 12-Lead EKG
tabs.content: Result: Sinus Bradycardia. HR 32. Prolonged QT interval (0.48s). No ectopy noted.

options.text: Maintain strict bed rest and notify the provider of unstable vitals
Encourage the client to increase fluid intake to 3,000 mL/day
Administer STAT IV Atropine to raise the heart rate
Re-check the blood pressure in the Trendelenburg position

rationale.correct: This client is showing signs of critical cardiovascular instability (a1). In anorexia, heart muscle atrophy leads to severe bradycardia and hypotension. A heart rate dropping significantly upon standing (from 40 to 32) and a systolic BP of 72 represent a failure of the autonomic nervous system to compensate, placing the client at high risk for syncope and cardiac arrest. Strict bed rest is mandatory until the client is stabilized via rehydration and nutritional support.
clinicalPearls: Wait-Standing vitals: In a healthy person, HR goes UP when standing. In severe anorexia, the HR may paradoxically go DOWN or fail to rise because the heart cannot handle the work.
Criteria for hospitalization in anorexia: HR < 40 bpm, SBP < 90 mmHg, or Temp < 96Â°F.
The mottled skin and long CRT indicate poor systemic perfusion (peripheral shutdown).

questionTrap.trap: Thinking Atropine (a3) is the fix for chronic starvation-induced bradycardia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Atropine is for acute, symptomatic bradycardia (like a block). In anorexia, the heart is physically shrunk and weak; pharmacological stimulation is often ineffective or dangerous. The priority is safety (bed rest) and medical stabilization.

mnemonic.title: Heart of Stone
mnemonic.expansion: Small heart, Slow beat. BP low, Stay on seat (Bed rest).
